topics.title: Category creation: what it takes to educate buyers
topics.summary: Barbra opens with what’s required to build a new category: analyst/directory validation, strong thought leadership, and lots of educational content so buyers understand why to budget for it.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces the show and Barbra’s background (Miro, Greenhouse, Culture Amp) and frames the episode’s three pillars: category creation, branding/rebranding, and opinionated software.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for AssemblyAI (audio/video AI APIs) and Stytch (authentication and onboarding).

topics.title: Barbra’s career and current startup
topics.summary: Barbra summarizes her B2B SaaS marketing career and introduces her new company, positioned as an “employee progression platform” aiming to replace performance reviews with better coaching and accountability.

topics.title: When to create a category vs compete
topics.summary: Barbra contrasts Miro (expanded from “online whiteboard” into “visual collaboration”) with Greenhouse (attempted category shift away from ATS but later abandoned), highlighting scope, budgets, buyer language, and competition dynamics.

topics.title: Defining “category” and giving examples
topics.summary: They define categories via directory/review sites (e.g., G2) as feature/pain-point groupings tied to budgets, then ground it with examples like marketing automation and customer success platforms.

topics.title: Benefits, risks, and Greenhouse’s failed attempt
topics.summary: Barbra explains why category creation can fail: even with differentiation, buyers still map you to the budgeted category (Greenhouse remained “ATS”). She describes pivoting from renaming the category to elevating the category’s perceived value.

topics.title: Miro’s path: no budget, but a vision
topics.summary: They unpack how Miro built “visual collaboration” despite limited pre-existing budget by aggregating many use cases under one umbrella, listening to how users described jobs-to-be-done, and keeping adjacent-category positioning in parallel.

topics.title: Signals to stop and how to create categories
topics.summary: Barbra shares when category creation is a bad idea (too established, not truly differentiated, message not sticking) and outlines mechanics: deep customer conversations, PR to test positioning, and analyst/directory alignment plus heavy content/thought leadership.

topics.title: Market inflection points and the middle ground
topics.summary: They discuss how category waves follow tech shifts (e.g., COVID/distributed work) and explore a hybrid approach: sell into an existing budget category while educating toward a new one (Pando: performance management now, employee progression long-term).

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor read for Vanta (SOC 2 and security compliance automation).

topics.title: Rebranding Miro: timing, buy-in, execution
topics.summary: Barbra explains why RealtimeBoard needed a new name, how leadership and early users were brought along, and what made the rebrand work: preserving brand essence, running it like a product project, cross-functional ownership, and managing high-risk dependencies (e.g., domain timing).

topics.title: Building a brand: values, systems, and voice
topics.summary: Barbra argues brand should be intentional early, tightly linked to product and company DNA, and expressed through values. They cover how values can shape visual/behavioral brand systems, how to create values (brain dump → group → vote → define), and brand components (logo, palette, typography, imagery, voice).

topics.title: Opinionated software: enforcing best practices
topics.summary: Barbra defines opinionated software as embedding best practices/rules (e.g., Atlassian for agile, Greenhouse for structured recruiting) and explains when to be opinionated: either codify an emerging process or teach a better way. She begins describing how her new product will be opinionated to reduce bias in performance reviews.
